title.narrative: Building a stable and peaceful Africa

description.narrative: Horn of Africa, North Africa and Sahel including the Lake Chad Basin region
Strengthening continental criminal justice and rule of law responses

To enhance knowledge, and improve policy and practice on the rule of law, governance and peacebuilding.
Outcome 1: Enhanced research-based knowledge on threats to governance, rule of law and peace building in Africa, and how best to respond
Outcome 2: Improved national, regional and continental strategy, policy and practice on governance, rule of law and peace building
Outcome 3: Strengthened donor programming in response to governance, rule of law and peacebuilding challenges in Africa

description.narrative: AFI held workshops held on the future of Algeria with country issue area experts, goverment and development agencies. title.narrative: Strengthening criminal justice and rule of law responses: Seminar on Community Resilience to Violent Extremism and Dialogue in Kenya and Uganda

description.narrative: CTAP launched the findings of studies in Kenya and Uganda related to community resilience to violent extremism and opportunities for dialogue within communities and between security/justice actors and VE groups.

title.narrative: Participants for the launches in Nairobi and Kampala included state representatives charged with implementation of P/CVE National and County Action Plans.

description.narrative: The launch of the study report and findings was a unnique hybrid model - both virtual and physical for participants in Nairobi and Kampala, while respecting COVID-19 regulations in Kenya and Uganda respectively. The discussions were particularly rich and indicated a continued need to develop these two aspects on P/CVE processes in both countries.

comment.narrative: Common understanding among policy makers in Kenya and Uganda on dialogue and community resilience in P/CVE processes
56 participants drawn from government and non-governmental organisations participated in the hybrid events in Nairobi and Kampala.

title.narrative: Strengthening criminal justice and rule of law responses: Seminar on Land, reparations and transitional justice in South Sudan (Juba, Torit, Wau, Yambio and Yei) on land and reparations in the transitionaljustice agenda in South Sudan

description.narrative: CTAP launched the findings of studies in South Sudan (Juba, Torit, Wau, Yambio and Yei) related to a study that links the land situation and reparations to the transitional justice process and revitalised peace agreement for South Sudan.

title.narrative: Participants in Juba included state representatives charged with implementation of land matters, National Human Rights Commission and CSOs.

description.narrative: The launch of the study report and findings was a unnique hybrid model - both virtual and physical for participants in Juba, while respecting COVID-19 regulations in South Sudan. The discussions were particularly rich and indicated a continued need to support and advocate for transitional justice processes in South Sudan.

comment.narrative: Common understanding among policy makers in South Sudan on transtional justice processes
47 participants attended the hybrid event at the Pyramid Hotel, Juba

title.narrative: Presenting research done on the Sahel at several events in Europe. Publication of an ISS Today on need for long-term development planning in the Sahel.

description.narrative: During this quarter African Futures and Innovation Programme (AFI) participated at various events in Munich (mid-February) that allowed the dissemination of the AFI report on the long-term future of the Sahel that was completed in 2019. The first was a discussion at the offices of the Hanns Seidel Foundation followed by a round-table discussion and a working breakfast meeting at the Fürstensalon, Bayerischer Hof, on the margins of the Munich Security Conference.

title.narrative: Peacebuilding and rule of law in the Lake Chad Basin

description.narrative: Findings enhance DDR and SPRR programmes and foster peace building across the four countries, supported by evidence-based research.

title.narrative: Quarterly ISS Todays to be published in April, June and September. Central Africa Report on DDR in the LCB published in English and French in Nov 2018

description.narrative: Feedback from the publication of the ISS Todays. Questionnaires filled out during dissemination activities. Referneces to outputs in key policy documents. Relevance of the research to the stabilisation plan of the Lake Chad Basin Commission.

baseline.value: Consultative visits in the region provide an understanding of the state of DDR as planned in the Lake Chad Basin stabilisation plan and initiatives underway at national level. Key observation remains the national responses brought to a regional problem without a clear understanding of how loopholes are appropriated by ex-combatants.

comment.narrative: Consultation, composition of the research team and beginning of field research process is ongoing during 2019 Q1 & Q2
Fieldwork completed in Borno State, Nigeria. Fieldwork also underway in Chad and Cameroon
Data analysis will start late October for the publication.

baseline.value: Need of evidence-based timely analysis on the socio-economic and political dynamics governance stabilization and social cohesion challenges these countries face against the backdrop of an expanding terrorist threat and in some contexts approaching electoral competition or recent leadership change.

comment.narrative: Evidence-based timely analysis on the socio-economic and political dynamics, governance, stabilization and social cohesion challenges these countries face against the backdrop of an expanding terrorist threat and in some contexts, approaching electoral competition or recent leadership change to support policy and feed directly into decision making processes.
Number of contributions made to enhance evidence based knowledge and undersatnding on the human secrity challenges facing the Sahel

The ISS conducted pre-election 2 consultative missions in Burkina and Niger, where the team met representatives of political parties, government institutions, civil society organisations, international partners, as well as researchers, and other relevant actors. The team also monitored the broader societal and socio economic developments in the Sahel. The data and information gathered and analysed through this work led to the publication of 4 analytical pieces, 14 presentations, 10 briefings and 19 interviews.

title.narrative: Number of briefings to other relevant national, regional and international stakeholders and partners

description.narrative: These are all the briefing sessions delivered to stakeholders other than command officers from all divisions of the JF-G5S headquarters and the senior leadership of the Permanent secretariat

comment.narrative: 1) Briefing to ECOWAS mission on the political situation in Mali, 16 July 2020 - At the request of the ECOWAS Office in Mali, ISS briefed the delegation of ECOWAS mediation mission on the resolution of the socio-political crisis in Mali. The briefing provided an opportunity to convey some key messages on the situation, particularly the urgency of laying out the foundations for a political process that would facilitate an irreversible implementation of essential governance reforms and forestall another episode of uncertainty in Mali and the region. 2) At the request of the Ministry of foreign Affairs of the Netherlands, the ISS organized a briefing on the ongoing political crisis in Mali. This briefing focused on the causes of military interference on the political scene, the intentions and reactions of the various national and international actors. Discussions also focused on the impact of these events on the security situation in the country and the region on 2 september and follow up on 15 september. 3) Briefing to Embassy of Belgium. Economic and political officer on 2 september on Situation in the Sahel. 5) Briefing to Dutch MFA on 9 september on Spillover of violent extremism to West African coastal states. 6) Briefing to Dutch foreign affairs officer in charge of stabilisation on 28 september on update of the situation. 7) Briefing to EU and EU member states political advisors from embassies in Dakar on situation in Mali on 29 september. 8) Briefing to OSIWA, Governance Unit Programme Head, 20 july, on Ongoing crisis in Mali. 9) Briefing to Members of the EU Sahel team, 23 july on Role of the EU in the Malian crisis after the ECOWAS mediation. 10) On Coup d'état in Mali to UNOWAS Sahel Team on 20 august.

1) Briefing to the delegation of Ireland on the security and socio-economic situation in the Sahel. 2) Briefing to West African Economic and Monetary Union peace and security delegate on the current secrity dynamics in the Liptako-Gourmal. 3) Briefing to representative of the University of Edinburghon C19 and peace processes in the case of Mali. 4) Several briefings on the Covid-19 situation in West Africa and the Sahel to : the World Food Program, the UK Conflict, Security and Stability Fund

1) Technical support to the Mauritania presidency of the G5 Sahel, the ISS was invited by the current Mauritania presidency of the G5 Sahel, to provide technical support for the organization a fourth conference on strengthening relations between defence and security forces and local populations in the G5 Sahel states. This conference is scheduled on 26 January 2021. The invitation by the host government provides opportunities to enhance the policy impact of analysis generated across ongoing research streams. 2)Upon request from the G5 Sahel Executive Secretariat, the ISS drafted a proposal for the organisation of an international Symposium on the current state and strategic priorities of policy-relevant research on violent extremism and radicalization in the G5 Sahel countries. The Symposium is expected to be implemented in partnership with USAID/ P for Peace. Following initial feedback from P4P in August, the Sahel team submitted a revised version of this proposal in September for a 6-month project. P4P update in November revealed that the proposal was still under review. Should the project be confirmed, an updated start date will be determined in 2021.

1) The G5 Sahel Executive Secretariat requested technical support from the ISS in organising a regional symposium on research into radicalization and violent extremism in the Sahel and West Africa. The Symposium seeks to create a framework for exchange between research centers and P/CVE practitioners. This should lead to the elaboration of a strategic research agenda for the G5 Sahel and other decision-makers in the G5 Sahel countries for the prevention of radicalization and violent extremism. The symposium originally planned for June has been postponed to november 2020 because of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

1) The G5 Sahel has requested support from the ISS in the organisation of an upcoming regional symposium on the theme: "State of the art in the Prevention of radicalization and Violent Extremism (PREV) in the Sahel" in partnership with USAID P4P. The overall objective is to rely on Strategic Research on violent extremism and radicalization in West Africa and the Sahel to better understand the phenomenon and effectively grasp the means and methods to eradicate it. - Upcoming
Number of non-security accompanying measures and development interventions

The overall objective is to rely on Strategic Research on violent extremism and radicalization in West Africa and the Sahel to better understand the phenomenon and effectively grasp the means and methods to eradicate it.

title.narrative: Number of seminars, conferences or workshops to which the project contributed

description.narrative: Number of seminars, conferences or workshops to which the project contributed

comment.narrative: 1) At the invitation of the Global Public Policy Institute (GPPI), the team participated in a virtual workshop on the theme: COVID-19: An Opportunity for a Reset in the Sahel Region? on 20 August. The team presented its initial analysis of how COVID-19 has exposed governance challenges in the Sahel, albeit not directly leading to major upheavals in the region . 2) At the invitation of the gold mining company IAMGOLD, the team presented analysis of the risks posed by upcoming elections in Burkina Faso and Côte d’Ivoire and the implications a deteriorating political and security situation could have on its operations on 27 August. This request shows the increasing interest for ISS research by the private sector. 3) The team was invited by the laboratory of analysis of societies and power (Laboratoire d’analyses des sociétés et pouvoirs LASPAD) of the University Gaston Berger of Senegal to a discussion on the Mali coup and future perspectives. 4) On 3 September, the ISS was invited by the CGIAR to participate as a panelist in a webinar on climate security in the Sahel. The ISS shared insights and analysis on the drivers of conflict in the Sahel and how climate-smart interventions can help to alleviate some of the root causes of conflicts in the region. Recordings of the webinar were later turned into a Global Dispatches audio podcast. 5) On 23 September, the ISS was invited by the Danish Refugee Council (DRC) and the Danish Network for Conflict Prevention and Peacebuilding to share its insights and analysis in a panel discussion on the impact of measures taken to prevent/mitigate the spread of COVID-19 on conflict dynamics and displacement trends, and changes in the structures, incentives and conditions for peace. 6) On 30 September, ISS was invited by the Konrad Adenauer Stiftung (KAS) in Brussels to participate in a closed webinar for EU policy makers on the Sahel. The webinar focused on issues of coordination and trust-building in the region, and against the specific backdrop of Mali’s current crisis.

1) Presentation of ISS data to the students-Officers of the 2nd promotion of the G5 Sahel Defence College, Nouakchott, 24-25 February 2020 2) Briefing to United Nations Development Program (UNDP) during its meeting for the Sahel Support Plan of the UN Integrated Strategy for the Sahel (UNISS), Dakar, 22 January 2020 3) Presentation on violent extremism, organised crime and local conflicts in the Liptako-Gourma region at the Accra Initiative ministerial meeting, Bamako, 14 January 2020 4) Invitation to participate in the Public Roundtable on the Prevention of Violent Extremism, Geneva, 30 January 2020 5) Invitation to make a presentation on the evolution of the insecurity in the Sahel, highlighting risks for coastal states and to share analytical perspectives on key security challenges in West-Africa at the UNOWAS bi-annual office retreat, Dakar, 30 January 2020 6) 2nd meeting of the Governors of the Liptako-Gourma Border Regions, Bamako, 10-12 March 7) ECOWAS and the United Nations Office for West Africa and the Sahel (UNOWAS) workshop on transhumance, Abuja, 10-11 February 2020 8) Presentation of ISS data to the students-Officers of the 2nd promotion of the G5 Sahel Defence College, Nouakchott, 24-25 February 2020

Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, several events have been cancelled or postponed. The team has nonetheless contributed to a few online seminars. 1) Invitation to present by the Open Society European Policy Institute in a webinar to assess and discuss European approaches to the Sahel. As European decision-makers re-examine their strategy in an increasingly prominent region in the EU’s foreign policy outlook, the discussion focused on improving the EU’s security engagement and its implications for longer-term governance and development in the Sahel, Bamako (online event), 19 May 2020 2) The ISS was invited by the International Peace Institute (IPI), the Stimson Center, and Security Council Report (SCR), which aims to support the sustained engagement of member states in broader discussions on making UN peace operations better fit for purpose. The presentation stressed the fact that the multiplicity and interdependence of the armed forces operating in the Sahel implies the need for a common ethics in action. The blunders committed by the national armies or a coalition of armies can have an impact on the efforts to stabilize the country. These abuses stir up disagreements between the SDF and certain communities and contribute to further weakening their relations with the state.

1) The briefing to the Deputy Commander of the Joint Force on the evolving security situation in the Liptako-Gourma region emphasized the need for the Joint Force to have a good understanding of the phenomena and the links between violent extremism, transnational organised crime and local conflicts to ensure the efficiency of operations. Discussions also focused on the challenges facing the Joint Force in link with human rights respect. 2) Within the framework of collaboration between the ISS and the G5 Sahel Defense College , the team was invited to present research findings to cadets of the 2nd promotion of the G5 Sahel Defence College on the following themes: violent extremism, transnational organized crime and local conflicts in the Liptako-Gourma; the logic of engagement and technical recruitment in violent extremist groups as well as on the responses of states and their implications for populations.

number of civilian and military staff in charge of implementing the Force's mandate who attended the briefing delivered by the project and improved their understanding of the risks and the environment of operation

The briefing to the Commander of the Joint Force on the evolving security situation in the Liptako-Gourma region emphasized the need for the Joint Force to have a good understanding of the phenomena and dynamics to ensure the efficiency of operations. Discussions also focused on the challenges facing the Joint Force, particularly in a context of increasing inter and intra-community violence.
